title: Chinese Government donates school backpacks to children in Tanzania in July 2021
description: On July 12th, 2021, a ceremony was held for the donation of school bags to local children by the Chinese Consulate General in Zanzibar. This was held in the Ministry of Education and Vocational Training Center of Zanzibar. Consul General Zhang Zhisheng and Sang's Minister of Education and Vocational Training Simai Mohammed Saeed attended the ceremony and signed the handover certificate. This batch of school bags will be distributed by the Tanzania government to the local children living in difficulties.
combined_text:
# Sector
EDUCATION

# Title
Chinese Government donates school backpacks to children in Tanzania in July 2021

# Description
On July 12th, 2021, a ceremony was held for the donation of school bags to local children by the Chinese Consulate General in Zanzibar. This was held in the Ministry of Education and Vocational Training Center of Zanzibar. Consul General Zhang Zhisheng and Sang's Minister of Education and Vocational Training Simai Mohammed Saeed attended the ceremony and signed the handover certificate. This batch of school bags will be distributed by the Tanzania government to the local children living in difficulties.
justification: Project is focused on educational support without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Donation of school backpacks to children, education sector focus

title: The Chinese Government donates 35,000 masks to Tanzania for COVID-19 relief in June 2021
description: On June 29th, 2021, the Chinese Consulate General in Zanzibar donated masks to Zanzibar at the Zanzibar Ministry of Health. Consul General Zhang Zhisheng signed a handover certificate with Omar Shajak, Permanent Secretary of the San Francisco Ministry of Health. This batch of supplies includes 30,000 disposable medical surgical masks and 5,000 N95 masks. The purpose of this donation is to help Tanzania fight against the pandemic.
staff_comments: AidData has estimated the transaction amount for this donation based on price catalogues from the World Health Organization (WHO). Please see the TUFF Methodology for additional details.
combined_text:

justification: Project is focused on healthcare support and pandemic relief with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Donation of 35,000 masks for COVID-19 relief, healthcare sector focus

title: China donates 12,000 masks and disposable gloves to Tanzania for COVID-19 relief in March 2021
description: In March 2021, Chinese Consulate General in Zanzibar donated 12,000 disposable medical masks and some medical surgical gloves to Zanzibar (Tanzania) Mnazi Mmoja Hospital and Abdulla Mzee Hospital to help alleviate the emerging threat of COVID-19 in Tanzania.
staff_comments: AidData has estimated the transaction amount for this donation based on price catalogues from the World Health Organization (WHO). Please see the TUFF Methodology for additional details.

title: China donates medical supplies worth TSh 348 million to Tanzania for COVID-19 relief in January 2021
description: On January 21, 2021, the ceremony of China's donation of anti-epidemic medical equipment to Zanzibar was held at the Zanzibar Ministry of Health. Consul General Zhang Zhisheng signed the handover certificate and delivered a speech with Simai Mohamed, Minister of Education and Vocational Affairs and Acting Minister of Health, Community Development, Gender, and Children. The donation was worth 348 million Tanzania shillings. The purpose of this donation is to help Tanzania fight against the COVID-19 pandemic.

title: China donates a batch of medical materials for COVID-19 prevention to Tanzania in August 2021
description: On August 18th, 2021, Tanzania's Minister of Health Ahmed recently accepted the COVID-19 vaccine and medicines assisted by the Chinese government on behalf of the Chinese Consulate Cangdao. The purpose of this donation is to help Tanzania through the COVID-19 pandemic. The exact amount of materials donated is unknown,

title: China provides cash donation of TSh 714 million to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Tanzania in December 2021
description: On December 13, 2021, The Government of China provided a cash donation of 714 million Tanzannia shillings to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and East African Cooperation. The donation is handed over by the Chinese Ambassador, Chen Mingjian, to the Secretary-General Ministry of Foreign Affairs and East African Cooperation Ambassador Joseph Sokoine in the Ministry's Sub-Offices in Dar es Salaam. Before the handover, Chen Mingjian and Ambassador Sokoine signed the Memorandum of Understanding regarding the donation as well as the Handover Document. The donation fulfills a pledge made by the Minister of Foreign Affairs of the People's Republic of China When Wang Yi made a business visit to Tanzania on 7 and 8 January 2021.  The purpose of this cash donation is to help build the capacity of the Tanzania Ministry of Foreign Affairs.
combined_text:
# Sector
GOVERNMENT AND CIVIL SOCIETY

# Title
China provides cash donation of TSh 714 million to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Tanzania in December 2021

# Description
On December 13, 2021, The Government of China provided a cash donation of 714 million Tanzannia shillings to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and East African Cooperation. The donation is handed over by the Chinese Ambassador, Chen Mingjian, to the Secretary-General Ministry of Foreign Affairs and East African Cooperation Ambassador Joseph Sokoine in the Ministry's Sub-Offices in Dar es Salaam. Before the handover, Chen Mingjian and Ambassador Sokoine signed the Memorandum of Understanding regarding the donation as well as the Handover Document. The donation fulfills a pledge made by the Minister of Foreign Affairs of the People's Republic of China When Wang Yi made a business visit to Tanzania on 7 and 8 January 2021.  The purpose of this cash donation is to help build the capacity of the Tanzania Ministry of Foreign Affairs.
justification: Cash donation for capacity building of government ministry, no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Cash donation to Ministry of Foreign Affairs for capacity building, no energy or infrastructure components

title: China donates anti-Ngiri disease medicial supplies to Tanzania in September 2021
description: On September 2, 2021, the Ministry of Health, Social Welfare, Elderly, Gender, and Children received the equipment for surgical equipment for gonorrhea surgery from China, which will be used for gonorrhea surgery in Unguja and Cahkechake Hospitals on the Pemba. According to Zhang Zhisheng, the Chinese Ambassador to Zanzibar, the purpose of this batch of medical equipment is to treat citizens with small boxes. He explained that at least 100 patients will benefit from the help to improve their health.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
China donates anti-Ngiri disease medicial supplies to Tanzania in September 2021

# Description
On September 2, 2021, the Ministry of Health, Social Welfare, Elderly, Gender, and Children received the equipment for surgical equipment for gonorrhea surgery from China, which will be used for gonorrhea surgery in Unguja and Cahkechake Hospitals on the Pemba. According to Zhang Zhisheng, the Chinese Ambassador to Zanzibar, the purpose of this batch of medical equipment is to treat citizens with small boxes. He explained that at least 100 patients will benefit from the help to improve their health.
justification: Project involves donation of medical supplies for healthcare purposes, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Medical equipment donation for gonorrhea surgery, healthcare focus

title: Chinese Government donates 3 million Sinopharm Covid-19 vaccine doses worth $54 million in July 2021
description: In 2021 and 2022, the Chinese Government donated approximately 5.565 million doses of Covid-19 vaccines to the Government of Tanzania. The Chinese Government delivered 3 million donated doses of Sinopharm Covid-19 vaccines to the Government of Tanzania on July 14, 2021. Two weeks later, on July 31, 2021, the Chinese Government delivered a batch of Sinovac COVID-19 vaccine doses and syringes to Tanzania’s Zanzibar Revolutionary Government.  The number of vaccine doses and syringes that were donated is unknown. Zanzibar Trade and Industrial Development Minister Omar Shaban and Chinese Consul General in Zanzibar Zhang Zhisheng went to the airport to greet and attend the handover ceremony. The Chinese Government delivered an additional 1,065,500 donated Sinopharm COVID-19 vaccine doses to the Government of Tanzania on October 8, 2021. The package arrived at the Julius Nyerere International Airport in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania. The Tanzanian government held a grand welcoming ceremony at Julius Nyerere International Airport on the same day. Minister Counselor Xu Chen of the Chinese Embassy in Tanzania, Minister of Health Guajima of Tanzania, Permanent Secretary of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs Sokoyne of Tanzania and other government officials, UN Resident Coordinator Milisik, heads of diplomatic missions in Tanzania and diplomatic envoys from many countries in Tanzania attended the event. Then, on November 1, 2021, the Chinese Government delivered 500,000 donated doses of Sinopharm Covid-19 vaccines to the Government of Tanzania. A handover ceremony took place in Dar es Salaam at the Julius Nyerere Airport. Chinese Ambassador Chen Mingjian, Minister of Health Dr. Guajima, Permanent Secretary of the Ministry of Health of Tanzania Macubi, Permanent Secretary of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Tanzania Sokoin attended the ceremony. activities and speeches. Several month later, on January 26, 2022, the Chinese Government delivered 800,000 donated Sinopharm vaccine doses to the Government of Tanzania. Two days later, on January 28, 2022, the Chinese Government delivered 200,000 donated Sinovac COVID-19 doses to Tanzania’s Zanzibar Revolutionary Government. The vaccines were handed over to a Representative of the Zanzibar Revolutionary Government, Minister for Education and Vocational Training Simai Mohammed Said, by the Chinese Consul General in Zanzibar Zhang Zhisheng at the Abeid Amani Karume International Airport.
staff_comments: . According to the UNICEF COVID-19 Vaccine Market Dashboard, the price of a single Sinopharm/Sinovac COVID-19 vaccine dose is $18 (https://www.oecd.org/officialdocuments/publicdisplaydocumentpdf/?cote=DCD/DAC/STAT(2022)33&docLanguage=En). As such, AidData has estimated the monetary value of the July 14, 2021 donation as $54 million.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Description
In 2021 and 2022, the Chinese Government donated approximately 5.565 million doses of Covid-19 vaccines to the Government of Tanzania. The Chinese Government delivered 3 million donated doses of Sinopharm Covid-19 vaccines to the Government of Tanzania on July 14, 2021. Two weeks later, on July 31, 2021, the Chinese Government delivered a batch of Sinovac COVID-19 vaccine doses and syringes to Tanzania’s Zanzibar Revolutionary Government.  The number of vaccine doses and syringes that were donated is unknown. Zanzibar Trade and Industrial Development Minister Omar Shaban and Chinese Consul General in Zanzibar Zhang Zhisheng went to the airport to greet and attend the handover ceremony. The Chinese Government delivered an additional 1,065,500 donated Sinopharm COVID-19 vaccine doses to the Government of Tanzania on October 8, 2021. The package arrived at the Julius Nyerere International Airport in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania. The Tanzanian government held a grand welcoming ceremony at Julius Nyerere International Airport on the same day. Minister Counselor Xu Chen of the Chinese Embassy in Tanzania, Minister of Health Guajima of Tanzania, Permanent Secretary of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs Sokoyne of Tanzania and other government officials, UN Resident Coordinator Milisik, heads of diplomatic missions in Tanzania and diplomatic envoys from many countries in Tanzania attended the event. Then, on November 1, 2021, the Chinese Government delivered 500,000 donated doses of Sinopharm Covid-19 vaccines to the Government of Tanzania. A handover ceremony took place in Dar es Salaam at the Julius Nyerere Airport. Chinese Ambassador Chen Mingjian, Minister of Health Dr. Guajima, Permanent Secretary of the Ministry of Health of Tanzania Macubi, Permanent Secretary of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Tanzania Sokoin attended the ceremony. activities and speeches. Several month later, on January 26, 2022, the Chinese Government delivered 800,000 donated Sinopharm vaccine doses to the Government of Tanzania. title: China Eximbank suspends debt service payments from Government of Tanzania in 2021
description: In response to the COVID-19 pandemic and the G20 Finance Ministers and Central Bank Governors meeting that took place on April 15, 2020 and on November 13, 2020, the Chinese Government agreed to work with other G20 members to implement the Debt Service Suspension Initiative (DSSI). Then, in 2021, China Eximbank and the Government of Tanzania signed a debt suspension agreement. Under the terms of the agreement, the lender agreed to suspend principal and interest payments due in 2021 under one or more loan agreements. The total estimated suspension amount was $91,489,000 ($71,260,000 in principal payments and $20,228,000 in interest payments). However, at the time that the parties signed the debt suspension agreement, they both acknowledged that the total suspension amount would ultimately be determined at the end of the suspension period (since loan disbursements could be made during the suspension period and the lender agreed to suspend the payment of interest accrued on any disbursements during the suspension period). The lender and borrower agreed that the suspension of debt service would be undertaken on a net present value (NPV)-neutral basis. Therefore, the borrower agreed to pay interest accrued on the amount outstanding under the total suspension amount (‘Suspension Interest’) by paying the Suspension Interest on the amount outstanding under each loan agreement’s suspension amount at the same rate of interest set forth in the original loan agreement.  Under the terms of the debt suspension agreement, the lender and the borrower also agreed that ‘[t]he suspension interest on the amount outstanding under the Suspension Amount concerning each Loan Agreement shall be calculated on the basis of the actual number of days elapsed and a year of 360 days, from and including the Repayment Date/Repayment Date of Principal and Interest falling within the Suspension Period to the date of payment in full of the corresponding Suspension Amount, and shall be paid in arrears on each Interest Payment Date under the corresponding Loan Agreement.’ The borrower also agreed that (1) ‘it shall continue to perform all its obligations […] under the Loan Agreements as supplemented and amended by [the debt suspension agreement]’; (2) ‘it shall use the created fiscal space to increase social, health, or economic spending in response to the COVID-19 crisis […]’ and ‘work closely with the International Financial Institutions who are expected to put in place a monitoring system’;  (3) ‘it shall disclose to the Lender all Public Sector Financial Commitments (as defined in the Government Finance Statistics Manual 2014 (GFSM2014)), respecting commercially sensitive information’; and (4) ‘it shall contract no new non-concessional debt during the Suspension Period, other than agreements under the DSSI’.
staff_comments: 1. AidData assumes that the same basic terms and conditions that governed China Eximbank’s DSSI (debt suspension) agreement with other governments also applied to its DSSI agreement that it signed with the Government of Tanzania. Illustrative DSSI agreements can be accessed via https://www.dropbox.com/s/huwa695j3w9hwig/DSSI%20Agreement%20for%20Kyrgyz%20Republic.pdf?dl=0 and https://www.dropbox.com/s/67n1oq44it27kvu/3.%20Debt%20Suspension%20Agreement%20for%20GCL%20Other%20Projects.pdf?dl=0 and https://www.dropbox.com/s/n69i598f0fg7s80/6.%20Debt%20Suspension%20Agreement%20for%20PBC%20C2.pdf?dl=0. 2. The total estimated suspension amount is based on the size of the debt service deferral that the Government of Tanzania secured from the Chinese Government in 2021 (as recorded by the World Bank's Debtor Reporting System on December 6, 2022).
combined_text:
# Sector
ACTION RELATING TO DEBT

# Title
China Eximbank suspends debt service payments from Government of Tanzania in 2021

# Description
In response to the COVID-19 pandemic and the G20 Finance Ministers and Central Bank Governors meeting that took place on April 15, 2020 and on November 13, 2020, the Chinese Government agreed to work with other G20 members to implement the Debt Service Suspension Initiative (DSSI). Then, in 2021, China Eximbank and the Government of Tanzania signed a debt suspension agreement. Under the terms of the agreement, the lender agreed to suspend principal and interest payments due in 2021 under one or more loan agreements. The total estimated suspension amount was $91,489,000 ($71,260,000 in principal payments and $20,228,000 in interest payments). However, at the time that the parties signed the debt suspension agreement, they both acknowledged that the total suspension amount would ultimately be determined at the end of the suspension period (since loan disbursements could be made during the suspension period and the lender agreed to suspend the payment of interest accrued on any disbursements during the suspension period). The lender and borrower agreed that the suspension of debt service would be undertaken on a net present value (NPV)-neutral basis. Therefore, the borrower agreed to pay interest accrued on the amount outstanding under the total suspension amount (‘Suspension Interest’) by paying the Suspension Interest on the amount outstanding under each loan agreement’s suspension amount at the same rate of interest set forth in the original loan agreement.  Under the terms of the debt suspension agreement, the lender and the borrower also agreed that ‘[t]he suspension interest on the amount outstanding under the Suspension Amount concerning each Loan Agreement shall be calculated on the basis of the actual number of days elapsed and a year of 360 days, from and including the Repayment Date/Repayment Date of Principal and Interest falling within the Suspension Period to the date of payment in full of the corresponding Suspension Amount, and shall be paid in arrears on each Interest Payment Date under the corresponding Loan Agreement.’ The borrower also agreed that (1) ‘it shall continue to perform all its obligations […] under the Loan Agreements as supplemented and amended by [the debt suspension agreement]’; (2) ‘it shall use the created fiscal space to increase social, health, or economic spending in response to the COVID-19 crisis […]’ and ‘work closely with the International Financial Institutions who are expected to put in place a monitoring system’;  (3) ‘it shall disclose to the Lender all Public Sector Financial Commitments (as defined in the Government Finance Statistics Manual 2014 (GFSM2014)), respecting commercially sensitive information’; and (4) ‘it shall contract no new non-concessional debt during the Suspension Period, other than agreements under the DSSI’.
justification: Debt suspension agreement with no direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Debt service suspension agreement, focus on financial obligations and COVID-19 response

title: Chinese Government donates medical supplies — including 3,000 oxygen generators and 1,500 blood oximeters — worth RMB 10 million in November 2021
description: On November 12, 2021, after his meeting with the Thai Prime Minister, the Chinese Ambassador to Thailand Han Zhiqiang presented 1.5 million donated doses of Sinovac COVID-19 vaccine and medical supplies worth RMB 10 million. The medical supplies included 3,000 oxygen generators and 1,500 blood oximeters. The RMB 10 million medical supply donation is captured via Project ID#88808.
combined_text:
# Sector
EMERGENCY RESPONSE

# Title
Chinese Government donates medical supplies — including 3,000 oxygen generators and 1,500 blood oximeters — worth RMB 10 million in November 2021

# Description
On November 12, 2021, after his meeting with the Thai Prime Minister, the Chinese Ambassador to Thailand Han Zhiqiang presented 1.5 million donated doses of Sinovac COVID-19 vaccine and medical supplies worth RMB 10 million. The medical supplies included 3,000 oxygen generators and 1,500 blood oximeters. The RMB 10 million medical supply donation is captured via Project ID#88808.
justification: Project involves donation of medical supplies and vaccines with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Medical supplies including oxygen generators and blood oximeters, COVID-19 vaccine donation
